repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Lagos Lagos Metropolitan
            Development and Governance Project : request for inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
This note presents the results of the
            first Inspection Panel ('the Panel') case under
            its 'pilot approach to support early solutions for
            request for inspection' ('the Pilot'). On
            September 30, 2013, the Panel received a request for
            inspection of the Nigeria: Lagos Metropolitan Development
            and Governance Project ('the Project'), and after
            consulting with the requesters and management, the Panel
            decided to consider this case under the Pilot approach. In
            addition to presenting the results of the case in the
            context of the Pilot, this note also provides insights into
            the issues that arose during the Panel's assessment of
            the case and the lessons that emerged from it. The Request
            for Inspection ('the request') was submitted by
            the Social and Economic Rights Action Center (SERAC) in
            Lagos, on behalf of 'individuals, families and groups
            living in the Badia area of Lagos State' alleging that
            the project has caused the 'impoverishment and
            insecurity' of Badia residents, a vulnerable slum
            community in Lagos, as a result of evictions that have
            occurred under the Project 'without prior consultation,
            notice, compensation or resettlement.' The requesters
            believe that they have suffered serious harm as a result of
            actions and omissions of the World Bank. They state that the
            Bank is 'clearly obliged to ensure that the project is
            implemented in accordance with its own operational policies
            and to hold Lagos State to its commitments under the LMDGP
            Project Agreement.' They add that on February 23, 2013,
            again, hundreds of structures were demolished in the area of
            Badia East immediately adjoining the canal mentioned above,
            forcefully evicting about 9.000 inhabitants. According to
            the Requesters, both incidences occurred without prior
            consultation, notice, compensation or resettlement and
            resulted in their further impoverishment. They add that
            since February 23, 2013, no relief or emergency aid measures
            have been provided to mitigate the extreme suffering of
            thousands of affected people. The Request refers to a number
            of interactions in which these concerns have been raised
            with World Bank representatives between March 2012 and July 2013.

Nigeria - Lagos Lagos Metropolitan
            Development and Governance Project : request for inspection

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Lagos Metropolitan Development
            and Governance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Lagos Metropolitan
            Development and Governance Project (LMDGP) for Nigeria were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            Bank teams should be cognizant of the prevailing political
            economy and calibrate the complexity of projects
            accordingly. A stand-alone case study is carried out to
            extract lessons learned from LMDGP in a more systematic
            manner, provide in-depth analysis of the modalities of urban
            sector engagements in a mega-city like Lagos, and make
            recommendations towards the structure and manner of
            engagement in such settings. Projects well vested into
            existing institutions are less vulnerable to the presence of
            political capital and may be better suited for complex
            environments like that of Lagos. Simultaneous deployment of
            various lending instruments proved to be effective in
            achieving desired outcomes. Lack of transfer of knowledge,
            right skill mix, and appropriate background in task team
            leaders (TTLs) and sector specialists affects the
            relationship with the client and poses a risk to
            implementation. When the Bank's and the client's
            commitment to safeguards policies and their practical
            implementation diverges significantly, both the Bank and the
            client should be upfront and eliminate instances where
            investments will trigger such policies.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Lagos Metropolitan Development
            and Governance Project : request for inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
On September 30, 2013, the Inspection
            Panel received a request for inspection ('the
            request') relating to the Nigeria: Lagos Metropolitan
            Development and Governance Project (P071340)
            (''the Project'). The request was sent by the
            Social and Economic Rights Action Center (SERAC) on behalf
            of 'individuals, families and groups living in the
            Badia area of Lagos State.' The requesters allege that
            the project has caused further 'impoverishment and
            insecurity' of Badia residents, a vulnerable slum
            community in Lagos, as a result of evictions that have
            occurred under the project 'without prior consultation,
            notice, compensation or resettlement.' The Panel
            verified that the request met the basic requirements for
            registration. However, based on the willingness of both the
            requesters and management to provide an opportunity to
            resolve the concerns rose, the Panel postponed its decision
            to register it and initiated instead the pilot approach to
            support early solutions in the Inspection Panel process.  On
            November 11, 2013, the Panel informed the board that it will
            review the situation within three months, as of February 11,
            2013, as stipulated in the pilot document. The Panel will
            wait for this expected progress, and will inform the Board
            by May 2014 on its decision, based on whether the Requesters
            are satisfied that their concerns have been successfully
            addressed (as set out in the pilot document).

TF040164-NIGERIA:LAGOS PILOT URBAN

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Lagos Metropolitan Development
            and Governance Project : request for inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
On September 30, 2013, the Inspection
            Panel received a request for inspection related to the Lagos
            Metropolitan Development and Governance Project (LMDGP) for
            Nigeria. The Request was sent by a civil society
            organization based in Lagos on behalf of individuals,
            families, and groups living in the Badia area of Lagos
            State. The requesters believe that they have suffered
            serious harm as a result of actions and omissions of the
            World Bank. They state that the Bank is clearly obliged to
            ensure that the project is implemented in accordance with
            its own operational policies and to hold Lagos State to its
            commitments under the LMDGP agreement. The requesters claim,
            that the evictions and demolitions have resulted in further
            impoverishment. The requesters state that on December 2012
            a retroactive resettlement action plan was completed and
            provided minimal financial assistance to 124 project
            affected persons displaced during the March 2012 forced
            eviction, the sums were insufficient to offset the harms
            suffered, especially in light or the delay of nearly nine
            months. They add that since February 23, 2013, no relief or
            emergency aid measures have been undertaken to mitigate the
            extreme suffering of thousands of affected persons. On
            October 31, 2013, and in line with the new pilot approach,
            Bank Management provided to the Panel a written note of
            actions given by Bank Management to address the concerns of
            the requesters, including an anticipated timeline as
            follows: a copy of the 2012 resettlement action plan (RAP)
            after the demolition or forced eviction in March 2012; a
            copy of the most recent revision of the 2013 RAP (or
            addendum to the 2012 RAP as was originally indicated), along
            with related documents; and clarification about the
            timetable for the setting up of the grievance mechanism with
            reference to certain deadlines identified in the Management
            actions. The Panel has decided to postpone its decision on
            registration to provide an opportunity for an early
            resolution of the concerns of the requesters under the
            pilot. In accordance with the steps set out in the pilot
            approach, the Panel will ask the requesters and management
            to engage in dialogue directly on these matters, and to keep
            it updated on progress in addressing the concerns of the
            requesters. Also, in line with the pilot approach, the
            requesters have the right at any time to indicate that they
            are not satisfied and will like the Panel to register their Request.

TF040164-NIGERIA:LAGOS PILOT URBAN
            UPGRADING PROJECT - EVALUATION,TF051122-PHRD-NIGERIA : LAGOS

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Lagos Metropolitan Development
            and Governance Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Lagos Metropolitan Development
            Project in Nigeria is a major investment in basic
            infrastructure towards improving the quality of life of
            Lagos State inhabitants, in particular, people living in
            slums. This will entail civil works, as well as
            rehabilitation works in slum areas, in water supply and
            sanitation, roads, drainage, power and other critical, basic
            infrastructure. The project will thus require displacement
            and relocation of people, currently residing around the
            proposed roads, or on other land intended for public
            infrastructure works. This Resettlement Policy Framework
            provides details on the populations affected, the regulation
            framework, the methods used to identify project affected
            persons (PAPs), the methods and scope of consultation with
            PAPs on resettlement issues, the resettlement and
            compensation packages, the institutional arrangements for
            implementing the RAP, its cost, special assistance to
            vulnerable PAPs, and external and internal monitoring.
            Eligibility for resettlement and compensation is based upon
            the country's legislation on resettlement, and the
            Bank's operational directive on involuntary
            resettlement. Any household identified as owning structures
            affected by the project is eligible for resettlement and
            compensation packages. Vulnerable groups will be compensated
            for any disturbance due to relocation. Social links will not
            be hindered by the relocation, and people will remain as
            close to employment opportunities as possible. Land for land
            compensation will be available for housing, and for
            commercial relocation as well.
